channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: Latika Bourke
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: Global COVID-19 cases pass 3.3 million; NSW nursing home under investigation; Australia’s death toll stands at 93

item.description: Follow our rolling coverage.
item.title: Tablet interactive: Coronavirus outbreak

item.dc:creator: Jewel Topsfield
item.description: Debate is raging worldwide over the role of urban density in the crisis, with some of the most crowded cities the hardest hit. How might Melbourne respond?
item.title: Melbourne in a post-pandemic world: how the virus could transform the city

item.dc:creator: Ben Schneiders
item.description: Australia has been far less generous to temporary migrant workers and international students than countries such as Britain, Ireland or New Zealand.
item.title: Starved out of Australia: The workers without money or food

item.dc:creator: Danny Weidler
item.description: Latrell Mitchell will no longer be the NRL’s poster boy as more details emerge that raise questions about his professionalism and approach to the game.
item.title: NRL ad axed as Mitchell faces more scrutiny over Test howler

item.dc:creator: Nick Galvin
item.description: This was Shari Sebbens’ year. Then COVID-19 struck.
item.title: The year that was: Shari Sebbens brings it all home

item.description: The finest photos from the wire agencies as chosen by our picture editors.
item.title: Best of the world in pictures

item.dc:creator: Chip Le Grand
item.description: The newly-appointed Sports Integrity Australia boss David Sharpe says while sport has stopped, the risk of corruption hasn't.
item.title: Time rich, cash poor athletes put sports integrity at risk, new tsar says

item.dc:creator: Zach Hope
item.description: The boutique bank has stunned customers by removing access to over-and-above loan repayments, supposed to be available to withdraw "at any time, for free", without notice or permission.
item.title: A time for 'Team Australia': ME Bank panned for blindsiding customers.

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: Education Minister Dan Tehan has also revealed that 1289 non-government schools have applied for the government's financial incentive to reopen classrooms.
item.title: Experts say half of students at risk from long-term remote learning

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: The federal government has launched the "Help is here" campaign as figures show a spike in reports to counselling services.
item.title: New domestic violence campaign launched as complaints surge during lockdown

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: Federal Education Minister Dan Tehan says 1.5 million university students should be back on campus by July.
item.title: 'Let's get the campuses open': Minister wants uni students back for semester two

item.dc:creator: Kathy Lette
item.description: We may have to take the word "men" out of Mensa. Why? Because it's women who are outsmarting the coronavirus.
item.title: A bit more femininity in the world wouldn't hurt at a time like this

item.dc:creator: The Herald's View
item.description: We cannot allow the government to use the COVID-19 pandemic to revisit their scotched plans of 2014.
item.title: Universities must return their focus to Australian students

item.dc:creator: Jordan Baker
item.description: The messy, high-stakes debate over when and how to re-open schools has led to the biggest rupture between the NSW Teachers' Federation and the state government in years.
item.title: Meet the gruff, theatrical warrior at the centre of the COVID-19 schools debate

item.description: To fight the coronavirus, Australians have embraced massive behavioural change - how do we keep up the good work?
item.title: We need good information and a little bit of nudging to maintain life-saving momentum

item.dc:creator: Max Koslowski
item.description: Australia's top coronavirus adviser at the World Health Organisation has refused to use it due to lingering privacy concerns.
item.title: Half of us say we support the COVIDSafe app, but only 16 per cent have downloaded it

item.description: Seeing her memoir become TV was both thrilling and terrifying for the American author.
item.title: 'I thought I was prepared': Deborah Feldman's past comes to life in Unorthodox

item.dc:creator: Peter FitzSimons
item.description: Captain James Cook's own words show him to have been a man of uncommon humanity.
item.title: Between ship and shore: emotions ran high for Cook's 250th

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: TV Week editor Thomas Woodgate was one staffer offered a voluntary redundancy.
item.title: Bauer Media sacks staff via Zoom

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet says students returning to school is critical for the economy.
item.title: 'Top of the list': a return to classrooms critical for productivity

item.dc:creator: Julie Power
item.description: Weeks of lockdown have taken their tolls on families. Psychologists are trying to broker peace, and address uncertainty and anger before it results in more serious long term damage.
item.title: 'It's a tinderbox': rescue kits to end COVID-19 family wars

item.dc:creator: Kristina Keneally
item.description: Our economic recovery must help all Australians get back on their feet, and to do that we need a migration program that puts Australian workers first.
item.title: Do we want migrants to return in the same numbers? The answer is no

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Measures introduced to combat the spread of COVID-19 have affected physical and mental health in unexpected ways.
item.title: 'We might have dodged a bullet': How COVID-19 restrictions affected our health

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: The caravan will move on and Labor will be part of the conversation again - it just needs to figure out what to say.
item.title: The incredible shrinking opposition or the shrewd alternative government?

item.dc:creator: Shane Wright
item.description: Shadow home affairs minister Kristina Keneally says "we must make sure that Australians get a fair go and a first go at jobs".
item.title: 'Put Australian jobs first': Labor calls for migration overhaul after pandemic

item.dc:creator: Dana McCauley
item.description: Private hospitals have been put on notice that Medicare data-matching will be used to detect any suspicious activity during the ban on most types of elective surgery.
item.title: Medicare data-matching to catch private hospitals flouting bans

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: The multibillion-dollar coronavirus shock to the sector has prompted a rethink of the international education business model.
item.title: Never waste a crisis: will COVID-19 be a catalyst for change at Australia's universities?

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: A decade ago, Victoria moved ahead with setting standards for personal bushfire shelters but NSW is still wary of following suit.
item.title: 'In the dark ages': Stoush brewing over bushfire bunkers

item.dc:creator: Zach Hope
item.description: Had you asked Ken Hanvey a year ago to download a data-gathering app because the federal government insisted on it, he'd have thought you quite mad.
item.title: Why a 'dyed-in-the-wool libertarian' decided to download COVIDSafe app

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: Women's heath and walking experts say there is a level of walking on neighborhood footpaths and streets "that people haven't seen in their lifetime".
item.title: On the move and off the merlot: a healthy iso habit worth toasting

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Paula Masselos prompted outrage when she urged visitors to stay away from Bondi - and that's not what Waverley Council voted for.
item.title: 'Locals only': How a mayor's rogue sentence reignited old tensions on the beaches

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Kylie Gough is reluctant to send her five-year-old daughter Mia back to school until the pandemic is over and is considering whether she will need to repeat kindergarten.
item.title: Parents ponder repeating their children after pandemic disruption

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: The coronavirus lockdown is a hammer blow to the economy but millions of Australians are financially better off, at least for now.
item.title: Millions of households better off with savings up while society shuts down

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: The puzzle of a Melbourne map that took two and a half years to draw has become a cult lockdown hit.
item.title: 'It took 8000 hours': A puzzle of Melbourne's heart is spreading lockdown city love

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: The outbreak that began with a teacher on March 22 has since infected 94 people in New Zealand.
item.title: A virus cluster at an Auckland school has Australian parents worried. Should they be?

item.dc:creator: Julie Power
item.description: Experts say Australia is lagging behind other countries, and risks an explosion of vehicles on the road, as the public shies away from public transport to maintain safe physical distancing during the recovery from COVID-19.
item.title: Call for wider footpaths, more cycling paths, slower streets to allow safe distancing

item.description: It is not only how other countries have managed coronavirus that will determine future travel plans.
item.title: Grounded travellers need refunds, not vouchers

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: As we turn a corner into a world with fewer shackles but more precautions, it's worth asking: what do we want to take with us?
item.title: It's not all bad: six keepers from life in lockdown

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: Chef Dan Hong is teaching home cooks to make prawn toast while actor Heather Mitchell is personally calling Sydney Theatre Company patrons to thank them for their support.
item.title: Instagram series and personalised mix tapes: how creatives are filling their time in the corona era

item.dc:creator: Gary Nunn
item.description: Extrovert Judy Sahay knew things were bad when she found herself chasing the Uber Eats delivery guy down the corridor of her apartment building, just to have a conversation with a real human being.
item.title: Introverts vs extroverts: How opposite personality types are handling lockdown

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Matches and messages have skyrocketed, but planning a first real-life date remains fraught.
item.title: Online dating surges as singles entertain themselves in lockdown

item.dc:creator: Genevieve Rota
item.description: Many of us have more time on our hands – or at least more time at home. Why not spend some of it taking a free art course from a range of esteemed universities?
item.title: Five self-paced art courses you can take for free on edX

item.description: Those piercingly loud powered hedge-trimmers just don’t cut it any more. Not when everyone has been told to work from home, study from home, stay safe at home.
item.title: No escape from the power-gardening pandemic

item.dc:creator: Kristina Keneally
item.description: Our economic recovery must help all Australians get back on their feet, and to do that we need a migration program that puts Australian workers first.
item.title: Pandemic offers opportunity to rethink immigration policy

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted in the work of our award-winning cartoonists.
item.title: Today's cartoons: The illustrated news

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, May 3, 2020

item.description: Collingwood's brain explosion in the 2018 AFL grand final holds a lesson for us all.
item.title: We'll stick together, but only if the pain is shared equally

item.description: Economists who count financial losses above lives lost do their field no favours.
item.title: The cure may not be worse than the disease, but it’s a nasty medicine

item.dc:creator: Chloe Booker
item.description: Wodonga’s mayor has called for an easing of Victoria’s coronavirus restrictions as the rules are set to relax in Albury across the NSW border.
item.title: 'Two sets of rules minutes apart': Wodonga's mayor calls for restrictions to ease
